{bc}to cause one to have or receive

{bc}to allow one to have or take

{bc}to collapse from the application of force or pressure

dt.t: The roof {it}gave way{/it} under heavy snow.
After several hours of debate, the opposition finally {it}gave way{/it}.

pt: {sc}give{/sc} {sc}present{/sc} {sc}donate{/sc} {sc}bestow{/sc} {sc}confer{/sc} {sc}afford{/sc} mean to convey to another as a possession. {sc}give{/sc}, the general term, is applicable to any passing over of anything by any means.

pt.t: {it}gave{/it} her a ride on a pony

pt: {sc}present{/sc} carries a note of formality and ceremony.
{sc}donate{/sc} is likely to imply a publicized giving (as to charity).
{sc}bestow{/sc} implies the conveying of something as a gift and may suggest condescension on the part of the giver.
{sc}confer{/sc} implies a gracious giving (as of a favor or honor).
{sc}afford{/sc} implies a giving or bestowing usually as a natural or legitimate consequence of the character of the giver.

pt.t: a development that {it}affords{/it} us some hope

et: Middle English, of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Swedish {it}giva{/it} to give; akin to Old English {it}giefan, gifan{/it} to give, and perhaps to Latin {it}habēre{/it} to have, hold
shortdef: to make a present of
to grant or bestow by formal action
to accord or yield to another

pt: {sc}pose{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} {sc}airs{/sc} {sc}affectation{/sc} {sc}mannerism{/sc} mean an adopted way of speaking or behaving. {sc}pose{/sc} implies an attitude deliberately assumed in order to impress others.
{sc}air{/sc} may suggest natural acquirement through environment or way of life.
{sc}affectation{/sc} applies to a trick of speech or behavior that strikes the observer as insincere.
{sc}mannerism{/sc} applies to an acquired eccentricity that has become a habit.
